change.item: MSS19970064 converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.xsl (sy2003-10-15).

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.repository: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center.
did.abstract: The collection includes notes, early drafts, both edited and unedited manuscripts, press proofs, galleys, page layouts, dummies, art work (sketches, scratchboard, acrylic, etc.), and correspondence with his editors and publishing companies for over fifty titles.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Leonard Everett Fisher, the well-known author and illustrator, was born in Bronx, New York, in 1924. Although his father was a ship designer by trade, he was also an aspiring artist. Through the influence of his father, Mr. Fisher learned of his own skills at an early age. By the time he was in second grade, he was already winning awards for his artwork. After serving in World War II as a cartographer, he attended Yale University's School of Art where he received his Bachelors and Masters degrees in Fine Arts. His first published book illustration was the book jacket for The Silken Secret, published in 1954. His first illustrated book, The Exploits of Xenophon, was published by Random House in 1955. Fisher's work covers a broad range, as he writes history, science, biographies, science fiction, legends, and poetry. Mr. Fisher has been honored with such awards as the Joseph Pulitzer Painting Fellowship, the William Wirt Winchester Traveling Fellowship, the Premio Grafico Fiera di Bologna, the 1981 National Jewish Book Award for Children's Literature, and the Christopher Medal, along with numerous others for his painting, writing and illustrating skills. In addition to authoring over eighty books, and illustrating more than two hundred and sixty, Mr. Fisher has also designed ten United States Postage stamps.

Mr. Fisher currently resides in Westport, Connecticut with his wife Margery. He has three grown children and six grandchildren who were often the inspiration for his books. Although he is well known and admired for his scratchboard drawings and his acrylic paintings, he also uses other media.

Some of Leonard Everett Fisher's books include The Great Wall of China, Gandhi, The Seven Days of Creation, The White House, and his more recent Cyclops, and Alexander Graham Bell (1999). Currently he is working on a new book, entitled The Gods and Goddesses of the Ancient Maya.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection includes notes, early drafts, both edited and unedited manuscripts, press proofs, galleys, page layouts, dummies, art work (sketches, scratchboard, acrylic, etc.), and correspondence with his editors and publishing companies. Book titles are listed in the following pages. There are also videotapes and audiocassettes of appearances and interviews conducted with the author.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: Series I: Books authored/illustrated by LEF (undated, 1927-1999).
Series II: Scrapbooks, Kidstamps & printing blocks listing.
Series III: Filmstrips created by LEF- artwork.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a significant collection of children's literature and related artwork. Contact the Curator for further information.

p.bibref: Something About the Author. Detroit: Gale; Anne Commire; 1983; pp.87-97, vol. 34.

"Leonard Fisher: A Giant among Authors." The Chronicle
[Willimantic, CT], Nov. 12, 1998; B6-B7.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on this collection.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Donated to the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center by Leonard Everett Fisher and his wife, Margery Meskin Fisher over a period of years ranging from August 1989 - the present.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additions to the collection have been received but are not yet processed and are, therefore, not represented in the finding aid. Please contact the Curator for Children's Literature for further information.

1979 Newsome Lecture. Louanne L. Newsome lecture ; 1979. Recorded at the University of Iowa,
Welcome to Mr. Fisher : Milan Elem., Eire Co., Ohio. Recording of student performances at Milan Elementary School in Eire Co., Ohio for Leonard Everett Fisher,

Bank St. talking about books : [Interview with Leonard Everett Fisher] Talk with children's book illustrator, Leonard Everett Fisher on the visual interpretation of classic literary and historical characters, the depiction of violence in media, and his latest work, The Cyclops. Recorded on Bank Street College Radio program on WNYE FM New York,

Aylesworth, Fisher, Fritz [sound recording] : radio, Stamford, CT. Recorded on the show "Footnotes from Ferguson" on WIRS FM in Stamford, CT. Two seperate episodes of the show "Footnotes from Ferguson," sponsored by Stamford, Connecticut's Ferguson Library, focused on children's literature. The host interviews 3 children's authors/illustrators on each program,

Art, books, and our children [sound recording] : [address delivered at] C.W. Post College, Oct. 8, 1968, roundtable conf., Tabco, Baltimore, 4/24/1969, S. Conn. Coll., 10/25/68 / [Fisher, Leonard Everett]. (Side A) Address delivered on four occasions, in which Fisher reflects on education and society in general, and the state of art in the late 1960s in particular. Fisher critizes the "primitivism" of current artistic trends, and its effect on the children's book and ultimately on a child's education. (Side B) Fisher discusses his career and his philosophy of art,
Conversation for 6 artists [sound recording] : paint a still life / L.E. Fisher and Charles M. Daugherty. Fisher discusses working on still lifes,

Conversation corner - WJER Radio [sound recording] : Leonard Everett Fisher. Recorded in Ohio. Fisher discusses his career as an illustrator including his winning the Pulitzer Painting Fellowship. He also discusses the importance of encouraging children to read,

Fisher, Leonard Everett [sound recording] : [two speeches]. [Side] A. Commencement address : Paier School of Art, 6/5/71 -- [Side] B. Seminar : National Art Education Association, Hilton Hotel, New York, Apr. 7, 1972. Seminar speech: Fisher discusses the more destructive impulses of creative artists in response to the seminars topic of "Men who create do not destroy",

L. E. Fisher : [two radio interviews] [Side] A and B. Norwalk stamp club : Radio WNLK, 11/28/72, 9:05-9:55 PM -- [Side] B WNYC-FM (New York) : the world of children's literature, 1-22-73, 4-4:30 PM/ 1-27-73, 8-8:30 PM. (WNLK) Fisher discusses his career as an illustrator, especially his work designing postage stamps. (WNYC) Augusta Baker reads from Fisher's Death of the Evening Star and interviews Leonard Fisher about the book, his interest in American history and its reflection in his books, his work on stamp designs and his career in general,

Books for children : Eve Merriam/Leonard E. Fisher. Marina Del Rey, Ca. : Audio Stats, 1981. Recorded 12/21/81 at an awards ceremony at the 71st Annual Convention of the National Council for Teachers of English in Boston,

L. E. Fisher: Imperial interview. Probably recorded in Fisher's home in Westport, Connecticut, and broadcast on a Norwalk radio station. Fisher on his book series on colonial craftsman, the origin of the idea, how he does his research, and how his does his drawings. He briefly talks about his first published work,

Stories of Latin America / [produced by Westport Communications Group, Inc.]. [New York] : Random House Educational Media. Table of Contents: Set 1. [1] Lora, Lorita / by Anico Surany. 52 fr. [2] Monsieur Jolicoeur's umbrella / by Anico Surany. 53 fr. [3] A jungle jumble / by Anico Surany. 57 fr. Set 2. [2] Ride the cold wind / by Anico Surany, 50 fr. [3] The golden frog / by Anico Surany, 45 fr. [4] The burning mountain / by Anico Surany, 45 fr.,

Stories of Latin America/ [produced by Westport Communications Group, Inc.]. [New York] : Random House Educational Media. Film strips : col. ; 35 mm. Adaptations of children's stories, designed to provide insights into the people and culture of Latin America. See also Audio 894 for accompanying sound,
The burning mountain / by Anico Surany, 45 fr.
The golden frog / by Anico Surany, 45 fr.
A jungle jumble / by Anico Surany. 57 fr.
Lora, Lorita / by Anico Surany. 52 fr.,
Monsieur Jolicoeur's umbrella / by Anico Surany. 53 fr.
Ride the cold wind / by Anico Surany, 50 fr.

University magazine: activities on and about the Central Missouri State University : [Children's Literature Festival episode, aired March 29, 1994] / production of KMOS-TV ; executive producer, Don Peterson. [Warrensburg, Mo. : Central Missouri State University, 1994] Stories include a profile of Kildip Rampal, a professor of mass communications at CMSU, and his studies on the media in Taiwan; visits to the CMSU Children's Literature Festival by author Jean Fritz and illustrator Leonard Everett Fisher; the CMSU rugby team; profile of CMSU student Terri Swopes, a CMSU student who juggles 3 part time jobs, caring for two kids, and attending classes at CMSU; dramatic adaptation of the story of Alladin by the CMSU Children's Theater,

Middle gate happenings- 1986-87: Guest author- Leonard Everett Fisher [1986] At an unidentified elementary school, Fisher signs books for children, and then tells about some of the techniques he uses in illustrating his books. He also talks about how his children's books are made,

Crosstalk: [interview with Leonard Everett Fisher]. Fisher discusses his career including his illustration work on historical subjects. He also talks about the distinction between his illustration work and cartoons,
Leonard Everett Fisher: WCYB-TV noon show interview. In a short news segment, Fisher talks about how he started writing books,
Leonard Everett Fisher. Leonard Everett Fisher talks about his design and advisory work on stamps and his meeting with President William Clinton,
Leonard Everett Fisher: [lecture at meeting for] NEEMA. Fisher talks about his conception of history and historical writing and its purpose,
LEF: Denton Ave. School, New Hyde Park, NY. Fisher talks about his work designing stamps and shows his Sleepy Hollow stamp design. He also illustrates the process of constructing a book,
LEF: Feb. 26, 1988, WLIO-TV News, Lima, Ohio. In a very brief interview, Fisher talks about for whom he writes and illustrates his books,

Leonard Everett Fisher. [Kankakee, Ill.] : Imperial International Learning. 1 sound tape reel : 3 3/4 ips ; 5 in., 1/4 in. tape. Meet the Authors, LI4608,
Leonard Everett Fisher : Live at One the Fairfield Exchange. Cablevision of Connecticut, Channel 12,
Leonard Everett Fisher : profile of an illustrator. Cleveland, Ohio : WVIZ,
